JUDGES: Karel Jungwiert;Mark Villiger;Mirjana Lazarova Trajkovska;Mykhaylo Buromenskiy;Peer Lorenzen;Rait Maruste;Renate Jaeger
TEXT: The applicant , Mr PERSON , is a NORP national who was born in DATE and lives in GPE . The applicant was represented by PERSON , a lawyer practising in GPE . ORG ( “ the Government ” ) were represented by their Agent , PERSON , of ORG .
The facts of the case , as submitted by the parties , may be summarised as follows .

On DATE the applicant , together with his wife and son , went to GPE for a private visit . At TIME they went to the bus station with the applicant 's sister - in - law , to catch the bus home . At the bus station CARDINAL persons wearing plain clothes approached the applicant as he stood alone outside the station hall . CARDINAL of these persons took the applicant by the arms , while the third said : “ Militsiya ” ( PERSON ) and waived a paper in front of the applicant 's face . The applicant could not read the paper .

The persons attempted to push the applicant into a minibus , which had no official police signs . The applicant resisted and the persons allegedly started beating him . They managed to handcuff the applicant and to push him into the minibus . Meanwhile , the applicant 's sister - in - law arrived and was thrust into the same minibus .
According to the applicant , he was further beaten in the minibus .

The applicant and his sister - in - law were taken to the Nakhimovskyy District Police Station in GPE . At the police station the applicant was forced to stand handcuffed against the wall for TIME . Subsequently , he was allegedly undressed and searched in the presence of his sister - in - law .

On DATE the applicant was questioned by the police , who enquired whether he belonged to a neo - NORP organisation , taking into account his hairstyle and the symbol on the t - shirt he wore . The applicant explained that he was a journalist ; that he did not belong to any type of extremist organisation and that he had come to GPE for private purposes .
The applicant 's wife went to the police station , where she was also questioned by the police and gave the same explanations .

At CARDINAL past CARDINAL in the evening of the same day , the police told the applicant that he had been apprehended on suspicion of being a member of the neo - NORP organisation “ S ” . The applicant remained in detention .
On DATE the applicant was taken to ORG ( ORG ) . The police officers told the applicant that he would be tried for failing to comply with their lawful orders .

On DATE a judge of that court found the applicant guilty of wilful disobedience to the lawful orders of the police , an administrative offence , on DATE , and issued a reprimand against him . The court 's resolution stated that it was final and was not subject to appeal . Subsequently , the applicant was released .

According to the applicant , the court proceedings were not public , as neither his wife nor his colleagues were allowed to enter the court room . The applicant was not given an opportunity to study his case file and to consult a lawyer either before or during these proceedings .
On DATE the applicant underwent a medical examination , according to which he was found to be suffering from minor bodily injuries which could have been caused on DATE .

On DATE the applicant complained to the prosecutors , alleging that he had been ill - treated by the police officers on DATE . In a letter of CARDINAL DATE ORG informed the applicant that on DATE the prosecutors had adopted a decision refusing to initiate a criminal investigation against the police officers . Relying on the findings of ORG , the prosecutors concluded that the police officers had not abused their power and that there was no indication that an offence had been committed . The applicant did not challenge the decision of CARDINAL DATE before the domestic courts since , in his view , it was based on the court 's resolution , which was not subject to appeal .
On DATE the applicant lodged with ORG a request for leave to appeal in cassation against the resolution of DATE under the new transitional cassation procedure .
On DATE the ORG informed the applicant that his appeal in cassation would be considered by ORG .

On DATE the President of the ORG quashed the resolution of DATE on the grounds that ORG had failed to verify the lawfulness of the orders given by the police officers and that it had applied a sanction which had not been envisaged by the relevant law . ORG remitted the case to ORG for fresh consideration .

On DATE the latter court invited the applicant to attend the hearing , scheduled for DATE . In his letter of DATE the applicant informed the court that he would not be able to attend the hearing for health reasons .

On DATE the applicant received a letter from the court inviting him to a new hearing , scheduled for DATE . According to the applicant , he was still undergoing medical treatment on the latter date and was therefore unable to attend that hearing .
On DATE ORG held a hearing in the applicant 's case and delivered a resolution , the relevant parts of which read as follows :
“ ... On DATE ... [ Mr ] PERSON wilfully disobeyed the lawful order of the police officers in the course of [ an ] identity check at the bus station in the town of GPE .

[ Mr ] PERSON 's guilt [ is ] proven by the reports of the police officers , [ PERSON ... ] , according to which [ Mr ] ... presented [ to PERSON PERSON ] a police identity card and informed [ him ] that [ he was ] being stopped by the police officers for an identity check . However , [ Mr ] PERSON tried to run away and resisted , thereby damaging the police officers ' uniforms . The police officers made similar submissions before the court ...

[ Mr ] PERSON failed to appear for the court hearing , [ although he had been ] repeatedly informed [ of the date and time of the hearing ] ; in accordance with his earlier submissions , [ he ] did not plead guilty , and explained that one of the police officers had showed him a police identity card , but [ he ] had not been able to read it . Thereafter , he was shown to the “ PERSON ” minibus . Since his sister - in - law told him that [ the persons apprehending him ] were not police officers , he started resisting , and that was why force had been used against him .
The court considers that [ Mr ] PERSON 's actions contain the corpus of the administrative offence envisaged by LAW of the [ Code on Administrative Offences ] .
However , since the time - limit for imposing administrative sanctions , provided for in LAW ] , has expired , the court considers that the proceedings against [ Mr ] PERSON must be discontinued .
Pursuant to ... , [ the court ]
Decided :
To discontinue the proceedings against [ Mr ] PERSON , PERSON .
The decision is final [ and ] is not subject to appeal . ”
The applicant was not informed about the date or time of the hearing of DATE . He received a copy of the court 's resolution on DATE .

Article CARDINAL of LAW , as worded at the material time , provided that administrative detention could be imposed and applied in exceptional circumstances for certain administrative offences for a maximum period of DATE .
Under LAW an administrative sanction could be imposed within DATE following DATE on which an offence was committed .

Article CARDINAL envisaged the following sanctions for wilful disobedience to the orders of a police officer : a fine in the amount of CARDINAL to CARDINAL times the statutory non - taxable DATE income ; a PERCENT salary deduction over a period of DATE ( corrective works ) ; or administrative detention for DATE , if , in view of the particular circumstances of the case and with regard to the personality of the offender , the imposition of more lenient sanctions appeared insufficient .
According to LAW , a copy of the resolution in an administrative offence case had to be handed over or sent to the person concerned within DATE following the completion of the case .

Pursuant to LAW , a first - instance court 's resolution imposing an administrative sanction was final and not open to appeal , save in cases envisaged in the law . Article CARDINAL provided that a prosecutor could lodge an extraordinary appeal ( “ protest ” ) against the court 's resolution . According to Article CARDINAL , a court resolution concerning an administrative offence could be reviewed either by the same judge who had adopted it in the first place , upon an extraordinary appeal lodged by a prosecutor , or by the president of a higher court on his or her own motion .

On DATE the ORG of Ukraine made changes to the LAW , by which it introduced an appeal procedure in administrative offence cases . In particular , under the amended Articles CARDINAL and CARDINAL of the LAW , the parties to administrative offence proceedings have the right to appeal against court resolutions in their cases within DATE following their delivery . Such appeals must be submitted through the court of first instance that adopted the contested resolution . That court must , within DATE , refer the appeal or appeals , together with the case file , to the court of appeal , which , in its turn , has DATE to consider the case . The cases are dealt with by a judge of the criminal chamber of the court of appeal in an open hearing . The judge has the power to reject the appeal , to quash the resolution and discontinue the proceedings or adopt a new resolution , and to change the resolution . The judge 's decision is final and not subject to any further appeal .
The relevant parts of ORG to LAW ( ETS No . CARDINAL ) prepared by ORG and submitted to ORG , which concern Article CARDINAL of Protocol No . CARDINAL , read as follows :

“ CARDINAL . This article recognises the right of everyone convicted of a criminal offence by a tribunal to have his conviction or sentence reviewed by a higher tribunal . It does not require that in every case he should be entitled to have both his conviction and sentence so reviewed . Thus , for example , if the person convicted has pleaded guilty to the offence charged , the right may be restricted to a review of his sentence . As compared with the wording of the corresponding provisions of LAW ( Article CARDINAL , paragraph CARDINAL ) , the word " tribunal " has been added to show clearly that this provision does not concern offences which have been tried by bodies which are not tribunals within the meaning of LAW .

CARDINAL . Different rules govern review by a higher tribunal in the various member ORG . In some countries , such review is in certain cases limited to questions of law , such as the recours en cassation . In others , there is a right to appeal against findings of facts as well as on the questions of law . The article leaves the modalities for the exercise of the right and the grounds on which it may be exercised to be determined by domestic law .

CARDINAL . In some GPE , a person wishing to appeal to a higher tribunal must in certain cases apply for leave to appeal . The right to apply to a tribunal or an administrative authority for leave to appeal is itself to be regarded as a form of review within the meaning of this article .
CARDINAL . Paragraph CARDINAL of the article permits exceptions to this right of review by a higher tribunal :
- for offences of a minor character , as prescribed by law ;

- in cases in which the person concerned has been tried in the first instance by the highest tribunal , for example by virtue of his status as a minister , judge or other holder of high office , or because of the nature of the offence ;
- where the person concerned was convicted following an appeal against acquittal .
CARDINAL . When deciding whether an offence is of a minor character , an important criterion is the question of whether the offence is punishable by imprisonment or not ... ”
